keyTakeAways: José Gregorio Hernández, a Venezuelan physician known as the 'doctor of the poor,' was canonized by Pope Leo XIV, marking Venezuela’s first saint.
The canonization occurred amid Venezuela’s severe economic crisis, mass emigration, and rising tensions with the United States, providing a moment of national hope and unity.
Pope Francis approved the canonization early in his final days, bypassing the typical miracle verification process due to widespread veneration among Venezuelans.
The event drew over 70,000 people, with thousands watching in Caracas via a large screen, highlighting the deep public resonance of Hernández’s legacy.

The ceremony also included the canonization of six other saints, including Peter To Rot of Papua New Guinea and Bartolo Longo, reflecting broader Catholic values of faith, sacrifice, and social justice.
The canonization coincided with the Nobel Peace Prize win of María Corina Machado, signaling a moment of cultural and political significance for Venezuela.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pope Leo XIV canonized José Gregorio Hernández, a beloved Venezuelan doctor known as the 'doctor of the poor,' marking Venezuela’s first saint. The event took place in St. Peter’s Square and drew over 70,000 people, with thousands watching in Caracas via a large screen. The canonization occurred amid Venezuela’s severe economic crisis, political instability, and rising tensions with the United States. Pope Francis approved the decision early in his final days, bypassing the typical miracle confirmation process due to widespread veneration. The ceremony also included the canonization of six other saints, including Peter To Rot from Papua New Guinea, and was celebrated as a moment of national hope and unity. The event coincided with the Nobel Peace Prize win of opposition leader María Corina Machado, amplifying its cultural and political significance.
title: Pope Leo XIV Canonizes Venezuela’s 'Doctor of the Poor' as National Symbol Amid Crisis
